title: Multilevel Propensity Score Analysis
text: Given large amount data summarized, use graphics integral component representing results. Pruzek Helmreich (2009) introduced class graphics visualizing dependent sample tests (see also Pruzek & Helmreich, 2010; Danielak, Pruzek, Doane, Helmreich, & Bryer, 2011). framework extended propensity score methods using stratification (Helmreich & Pruzek, 2009). particular, representation confidence intervals relative unit line (.e. line y=x) provided new way determining whether statistically significant diﬀerence two groups. multilevelPSA package provides number graphing functions extend frameworks multilevel PSA. figure represents multilevel PSA assessment plot annotations. graphic represents results comparing private public schools North America using Programme International Student Assessment (PISA; Organisation Economic Co-Operation Development, 2009). PISA data create graphic included multilevelPSA package detailed description create graphic discussed next section. Additionally, use PISA makes visible certain features graphics used. discussed chapters four five, diﬀerences charter traditional public schools minimal therefore features figures less apparent. following section focuses features graphic. figure , x-axis corresponds math scores private schools y-axis corresponds public school maths cores. colored circle () country size corresponding number students sampled within country. country projected lower left, parallel unit line, tick mark placed line slope -1 (b). tick marks represent distribution diﬀerences private public schools across countries. Diﬀerences aggregated (weighted size) across countries. math, overall adjusted mean private schools 487, overall adjusted mean public schools 459 represented horizontal (c) vertical (d) blue lines, respectively. dashed blue line parallel unit line (e) corresponds overall adjusted mean diﬀerence likewise, dashed green lines (f) correspond confidence interval. Lastly, rug plots along right top edges graphic (g) correspond distribution country’s overall mean private public school math scores, respectively. figure represents large amount data provides insight data results. figure provides overall results present traditional table, instance fact green dashed lines span unit line (.e. y = x) indicates statistically significant diﬀerence two groups. However additional information diﬃcult convey tabular format. example, rug plots indicate spread performance private public schools across countries large. Also observe Canada, largest PISA scores groups, also largest diﬀerence (favor private schools) represented larger distance unit line. Annotated multilevel PSA assessment plot. plot compares private schools (x- axis) public schools (y-axis) North America Programme International Student Assessment.

title: Multilevel Propensity Score Analysis
text: multilevelPSA package includes North American data Programme International Student Assessment (PISA; Organisation Economic Co-Operation Development, 2009). data made freely available research utilized R code reproducible9. example compares performance private public schools clustered country. Note PISA provide five plausible values academic scores since students complete subset total assessment. simplicity, math score used analysis average five plausible scores. mlpsa.ctree function performs phase propensity score analysis using classification trees, specifically using ctree function party package. getStrata function returns data frame number rows equivalent original data frame indicating stratum student. Similarly, mlpsa.logistic estimates propensity scores using logistic regression. getPropensityScores function returns data frame number rows equivalent original data frame. covariate.balance function calculates balance statistics covariate estimating eﬀect covariate adjustment. results can converted data frame view numeric results plot function provides balance plot. figure depicts eﬀect size covariate (blue triangle) (red circle) propensity score adjustment. shown , eﬀect size nearly covariates smaller unadjusted eﬀect size. exceptions covariates unadjusted eﬀect size already small. established threshold considered suﬃciently small eﬀect size. general, recommend adjusted eﬀect sizes less 0.1 reflect less 1% variance explained. Multilevel PSA balance plot PISA. eﬀect sizes (standardized mean diﬀerences) covariate provided PSA adjustment (blue triangles) PSA adjustment (red circles). mlpsa function performs phase II propensity score analysis requires four parameters: response variable, treatment indicator, stratum, clustering indicator. minN parameter (defaults five) indicates minimum stratum size included analysis. example, 463, less one percent students removed stratum (leaf node classification trees) contain least five students treatment control groups. summary function provides overall treatment estimates well level one two summaries. plot function creates multilevel assessment plot. depicted side panels showing distribution math scores strata public school students left private school students . panels can plotted separately using mlpsa.circ.plot mlpsa.distribution.plot functions. Multilevel PSA assessment plot PISA. main panel provides adjusted mean private (x-axis) public (y-axis) country. left lower panels provide mean stratum public private students, respectively. overall adjusted mean diﬀerence represented dashed blue line 95% confidence interval dashed green lines. statistically significant diﬀerence private public school student performance evidenced confidence interval spanning zero (.e. crossing unit line y=x. Lastly, mlpsa.difference.plot function plots overall diﬀerences. sd parameter optional, specified, x-axis can interpreted standardized eﬀect sizes. Multilevel PSA diﬀerence plot PISA. blue dot corresponds eﬀect size (standardized mean diﬀerence) country. vertical blue line corresponds overall eﬀect size countries. green lines correspond 95% confidence intervals. dashed green lines Bonferroni-Sidak (c.f. Abdi, 2007) adjusted confidence intervals. size dot proportional sample size within country.
code: library(multilevelPSA) library(party) data(pisana) data(pisa.psa.cols) pisana$MathScore <- apply(pisana[,paste0('PV', 1:5, 'MATH')], 1, sum) / 5 mlpsa <- mlpsa.ctree(pisana[,c('CNT', 'PUBPRIV', pisa.psa.cols)],                       formula = PUBPRIV ~ .,                       level2 = 'CNT') mlpsa.df <- getStrata(mlpsa, pisana, level2 = 'CNT') mlpsa.lr <- mlpsa.logistic(pisana[,c('CNT', 'PUBPRIV', pisa.psa.cols)],                             formula = PUBPRIV ~ .,                             level2 = 'CNT') mlpsa.lr.df <- getPropensityScores(mlpsa.lr, nStrata = 5) head(mlpsa.lr.df) #>   level2   ps strata #> 1    CAN 0.92      2 #> 2    CAN 0.94      3 #> 3    CAN 0.97      4 #> 4    CAN 0.93      2 #> 5    CAN 0.84      1 #> 6    CAN 0.97      4 cv.bal <- covariate.balance(covariates = pisana[,pisa.psa.cols],                             treatment = pisana$PUBPRIV,                             level2 = pisana$CNT,                             strata = mlpsa.df$strata) head(as.data.frame(cv.bal)) #>                        covariate es.adj es.adj.wtd es.unadj #> 1                    (Intercept)  0.000    0.0e+00      NaN #> 2 ST05Q01Yes, more than one year  0.097    2.3e-04    0.287 #> 3   ST05Q01Yes, one year or less  0.051    6.6e-05    0.220 #> 4               ST07Q01Yes, once  0.103   -1.1e-03    0.235 #> 5      ST07Q01Yes, twice or more  0.044   -3.7e-04    0.087 #> 6         ST10Q01<ISCED level 2>  0.030   -1.7e-04    0.171 plot(cv.bal) results.psa.math <- mlpsa(response = mlpsa.df$MathScore,                           treatment = mlpsa.df$PUBPRIV,                           strata = mlpsa.df$strata,                           level2 = mlpsa.df$CNT) #> Removed 463 (0.696%) rows due to stratum size being less than 5 summary(results.psa.math) #> Multilevel PSA Model of 85 strata for 3 levels. #> Approx t: -10.8 #> Confidence Interval: -31.3, -24.75 #>    level2  strata Treat Treat.n Control Control.n ci.min ci.max #> 1     CAN Overall   579    1625     513     21093    -72  -59.6 #> 2    <NA>       1   580      28     492      1128     NA     NA #> 3    <NA>       2   600       9     476      1326     NA     NA #> 4    <NA>       3   585      11     513       630     NA     NA #> 5    <NA>       4   571     140     508      2240     NA     NA #> 6    <NA>       5   578       8     470       179     NA     NA #> 7    <NA>       6   500      19     447       310     NA     NA #> 8    <NA>       7   584      83     503      3276     NA     NA #> 9    <NA>       8   471       5     464       120     NA     NA title: Multilevel Propensity Score Analysis
text: can seen recent Special Issue MBR propensity score analysis (PSA) methods, use PSA gained increasing popularity estimating causal effects observational studies. However, PSA use multilevel clustered data limited, date seems development specialized graphics data. paper introduces multilevelPSA (http://multilevelPSA.r-forge.r-project.org) package R provides cluster-based functions estimating propensity scores well graphics exhibit results multilevel data. work extends multilevel case framework visualizing propensity score analysis introduced Helmreich Pruzek (2009). International data Programme International Student Assessment (Organization Economic Co-operation Development, 2009) comprehensively examined compare private public schools reading, mathematics, science outcomes adjusting covariate differences multilevel context. Particularly analyses large data sets, focusing statistical significance limiting. can readily seen, overall results favor “private” “public” schools, least end secondary school math achievement. graphics provide nuanced understanding nature magnitude adjusted differences countries. Furthermore, graphics readily interpreted nontechnical audience. Broadly speaking, seen modern graphics can enhance extend conventional numerical summaries focusing details data say multilevel comparisons many countries based propensity score methods.

previous_headings: multilevelPSA - An R package for estimating and visualizing multilevel propensity score models
title: Multilevel Propensity Score Analysis
text: following example demonstrates get started multilevelPSA package. detailed explaination available package vignette (vignette(topic = 'multilevelPSA')). Example estimating effects private versus public schools North America using 2009 Programme International Student Assessment.
code: # Install from CRAN install.packages('multilevelPSA')  # Or install the package from Github remotes::install_github('multilevelPSA', 'jbryer') # Load the packages library(multilevelPSA) library(party)  # Load the Programme for International Student Assessment data data("pisana", package = 'multilevelPSA') data("pisa.psa.cols", package = 'multilevelPSA')  # Estimate the propensity scores mlctree <- mlpsa.ctree(pisana[,c('CNT','PUBPRIV',pisa.psa.cols)],                         formula = PUBPRIV ~ .,                        level2 = 'CNT')  # Get the strata student.party <- getStrata(mlctree, pisana, level2 = 'CNT')  # Create a total math score as the average of the five imputed scores student.party$mathscore <- apply(student.party[,paste0('PV', 1:5, 'MATH')], 1, sum) / 5  # Estimate the causal effects results.psa.math <- mlpsa(response=student.party$mathscore,                           treatment=student.party$PUBPRIV,                           strata=student.party$strata,                           level2=student.party$CNT, minN=5)  # Plot the results plot(results.psa.math)

code: covariateBalance(   covariates,   treatment,   propensity,   strata = NULL,   int = NULL,   tree = FALSE,   minsize = 2,   universal.psd = TRUE,   trM = 0,   absolute.es = TRUE,   trt.value = NULL,   use.trt.var = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE,   xlim = NULL,   plot.strata = TRUE,   na.rm = TRUE,   ... )

title: Calculate covariate effect size differences before and after stratification. — covariateBalance
text: covariates dataframe interest treatment binary vector 0s 1s (necessarily? character, 1, 2?) propensity PS scores method . strata either vector strata number row covariate, one number n case attempted group rows ps scores n strata size approximately 1/n.  seem work well case specific propensity values, tree. int either number m used divide [0,1] m equal length subintervals, vector cut points 0    1 defining subintervals (perhaps suggested loess.psa).  either case subintervals define strata, strata can size. tree logical, unique ps scores , recursively partitioned tree, TRUE force ps value define stratum. minsize smallest allowable stratum-treatment size.  violated, strata removed. universal.psd 'TRUE', forces standard deviations used unadjusted stratification. trM trimming proportion mean calculations. absolute.es logical, 'TRUE' routine uses absolute values effect sizes. trt.value allows user specify value active treatment, desired. use.trt.var logical, true Rubin-Stuart method using treatment variance used effect size calculations. verbose logical, controls output visibly returned. xlim limits x-axis. plot.strata logical indicating whether print strata. na.rm missing values removed. ... currently unused.

title: Loess plot with density distributions for propensity scores and outcomes on top and right, respectively. — loess.plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ require(multilevelPSA) require(party) data(pisana) data(pisa.psa.cols) cnt = 'USA' #Can change this to USA, MEX, or CAN pisana2 = pisana[pisana$CNT == cnt,] pisana2$treat <- as.integer(pisana2$PUBPRIV) %% 2 lr.results <- glm(treat ~ ., data=pisana2[,c('treat',pisa.psa.cols)], family='binomial') st = data.frame(ps=fitted(lr.results),          math=apply(pisana2[,paste('PV', 1:5, 'MATH', sep='')], 1, mean),          pubpriv=pisana2$treat)         st$treat = as.logical(st$pubpriv) loess.plot(st$ps, response=st$math, treatment=st$treat, percentPoints.control = 0.4,             percentPoints.treat=0.4) } # }

title: Plots the results of a multilevel propensity score model. — mlpsa.circ.plot
code: mlpsa.circ.plot(   x,   xlab = names(multilevelPSA$level2.summary)[4],   ylab = names(multilevelPSA$level2.summary)[5],   legendlab = "Level 2",   title = NULL,   overall.col = "blue",   overall.ci.col = "green",   level1.plot = FALSE,   level1.point.size = NULL,   level1.rug.plot = NULL,   level1.projection.lines = FALSE,   level2.plot = TRUE,   level2.point.size = NULL,   level2.rug.plot = "tr",   level2.projection.lines = TRUE,   level2.label = FALSE,   unweighted.means = FALSE,   weighted.means = FALSE,   fill.colors = NULL,   plot.adjusted.means = TRUE,   ... )

title: Plots the results of a multilevel propensity score model. — mlpsa.circ.plot
text: x results [mlpsa()]. xlab label x-axis. ylab label y-axis. legendlab label legend, NULL exclude. title title figure. overall.col color used overall results. overall.ci.col color used confidence intervals. level1.plot logical value indicating whether level 1 points plotted. level1.point.size size level 1 points level1.rug.plot placement plotting level 2 rug. Possible values bl (left bottom), tr (top right), NULL (exclude). level1.projection.lines logical value indicating whether level 1 project lines (parallel unit line) drawn. level2.plot logical value indicating whether level 2 points plotted. level2.point.size size level 2 points level2.rug.plot placement plotting level 2 rug. Possible values bl (left bottom), tr (top right), NULL (exclude). level2.projection.lines logical value indicating whether level 2 project lines (parallel unit line) drawn. level2.label logical value indicating whether level 2 points labeled. unweighted.means logical value indicating whether horizontal vertical lines drawn representing unweighted (.e. unadjusted phase PSA) means level 2, cluster. weighted.means logical value indicating whether horizontal vertical lines drawn representing weighted means level 2, cluster. fill.colors specified, colors use level 2 points. plot.adjusted.means whether plot verticial horizontal lines adjsuted means. ... currently unused.

title: Plots the results of a multilevel propensity score model. — mlpsa.circ.plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data(pisana) data(pisa.colnames) data(pisa.psa.cols) mlctree = mlpsa.ctree(pisana[,c('CNT','PUBPRIV',pisa.psa.cols)],                        formula=PUBPRIV ~ ., level2='CNT') student.party = getStrata(mlctree, pisana, level2='CNT') student.party$mathscore = apply(student.party[,paste0('PV', 1:5, 'MATH')], 1, sum) / 5 results.psa.math = mlpsa(response=student.party$mathscore,         treatment=student.party$PUBPRIV,         strata=student.party$strata,         level2=student.party$CNT, minN=5) mlpsa.circ.plot(results.psa.math, legendlab=FALSE) } # }

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data(pisana) data(pisa.colnames) data(pisa.psa.cols) mlctree = mlpsa.ctree(pisana[,c('CNT','PUBPRIV',pisa.psa.cols)], formula=PUBPRIV ~ ., level2='CNT') student.party = getStrata(mlctree, pisana, level2='CNT') student.party$mathscore = apply(student.party[,paste0('PV', 1:5, 'MATH')], 1, sum) / 5 results.psa.math = mlpsa(response=student.party$mathscore,         treatment=student.party$PUBPRIV,         strata=student.party$strata,         level2=student.party$CNT, minN=5) mlpsa.difference.plot(results.psa.math, sd=mean(student.party$mathscore, na.rm=TRUE)) } # }

what: This function will perform phase II of the multilevel propensity score analysis. — mlpsa

title: This function will perform phase II of the multilevel propensity score analysis. — mlpsa
code: mlpsa(   response,   treatment = NULL,   strata = NULL,   level2 = NULL,   minN = 5,   reverse = FALSE,   ci.level = 0.05 )

title: This function will perform phase II of the multilevel propensity score analysis. — mlpsa
text: response vector containing response values treatment vector containing treatment conditions strata vector containing strata response level2 vector containing level 2 specifications minN minimum number subjects per strata strata included analysis. reverse reverse order treatment control difference calculation. ci.level confidence level use confidence intervals. Defaults 95% confidence level.

title: This function will perform phase II of the multilevel propensity score analysis. — mlpsa
text: mlpsa class

title: This function will perform phase II of the multilevel propensity score analysis. — mlpsa
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ require(multilevelPSA) require(party) data(pisana) data(pisa.colnames) data(pisa.psa.cols) mlctree = mlpsa.ctree(pisana[,c('CNT','PUBPRIV',pisa.psa.cols)], formula=PUBPRIV ~ ., level2='CNT') student.party = getStrata(mlctree, pisana, level2='CNT') student.party$mathscore = apply(student.party[,paste0('PV', 1:5, 'MATH')], 1, sum) / 5 results.psa.math = mlpsa(response=student.party$mathscore,         treatment=student.party$PUBPRIV,         strata=student.party$strata,         level2=student.party$CNT, minN=5) results.psa.math summary(results.psa.math) } # }

title: Multilevel Propensity Score Analysis — multilevelPSA-package
text: packages provides functions estimate visualize multilevel propensity score analysis.

title: Multilevel Propensity Score Analysis — multilevelPSA-package
text: package extends principles put forth PSAgraphics (Helmreich, Pruzek, & Xiong, 2010) multilevel, clustered, data. Propensity score analyses typically done two phases. phase , statistical model predicting treatment using available individual covariates estimated. package currently currently provides functions perform propensity score estimates using logistic regression (see [mlpsa.logistic()]) conditional inference trees (see [mlpsa.ctree()]). latter method provides explicit stratifications defined leaf node. former however, results numerical value ranging zero one (.e. fitted values). common approach create stratifications using quintiles. However, approaches Loess regression also provided. Phase II typical propensity score analyses concerns comparison outcome treatment comparison groups. [mlpsa()] method perform analysis multilevel, clustered, fashion. , results [mlpsa()] procedure produce summary results level one (.e. strata within cluster), level two (.e. overall results cluster), overall (.e. overall results across clusters). package also provides number visualizations provide critical part presenting, understanding, interpreting results. See [plot.mlpsa()] details.

title: Multilevel Propensity Score Analysis — multilevelPSA-package

what: Heat map representing variables used in a conditional inference tree across level 2 variables. — tree.plot
title: Heat map representing variables used in a conditional inference tree across level 2 variables. — tree.plot
text: figure provides summary covariates used within level two cluster along relative importance. Covariates listed y-axis level two clusters along x-axis. Cells shaded indicate covariate present conditional. shade color represents highest level within tree covariate appeared. , darkest color, depth 1, corresponds covariate used root tree, first split.

code: tree.plot(   x,   colNames,   level2Col,   colLabels = NULL,   color.high = "azure",   color.low = "steelblue",   color.na = "white",   ... )

title: Heat map representing variables used in a conditional inference tree across level 2 variables. — tree.plot
text: x results [mlpsa.ctree()] colNames columns include graphic level2Col name level 2 column. colLabels column labels use. data frame two columns, first column match values trees second column description used labeling variables. color.high color variables less relative importance determined occurring later tree (root split). color.low color variables greater relative importance determined occurring sooner tree (closer root split). color.na color variables occur tree. ... currently unused.

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ require(party) data(pisana) data(pisa.colnames) data(pisa.psa.cols) mlctree = mlpsa.ctree(pisana[,c('CNT','PUBPRIV',pisa.psa.cols)], formula=PUBPRIV ~ ., level2='CNT') student.party = getStrata(mlctree, pisana, level2='CNT') tree.plot(mlctree, level2Col=pisana$CNT) } # }

text: CRAN release: 2015-11-05 use brewer color scheme 8 fewer levels. Update new version xtable package.

title: multilevelPSA 1.2.2
text: CRAN release: 2014-11-25 Added ci.adjust paramter mlpsa function specify confidence level (default 0.05). Added Bonferroni-Sidak adjusted confidence intervals based number levels/clusters returned mlpsa package diff.wtd data frame. mlpsa.difference.plot function plot confidence intervals dashed green line Changed factors dummy coded balance functions decrease execution time. Updated psranges add support classification trees (using ctree party package). Updated newest version roxygen2 Various updates CRAN check

title: multilevelPSA 1.2.1
text: Fixed position overall difference level 2 left margin strata much smaller overall difference. Added xlim parameter mlpsa.diff.plot function. Removed duplicated column pisana data frame.

title: multilevelPSA 1.2
text: CRAN release: 2013-05-10 Added covariate.balance corresponding plot function visualize covariate effect sizes propensity score adjustment. getPropensityScore method also return strata. number strata configurable function parameter. Added parameters loess.plot control number points plot (sampling percentage) well transparency level. Added reverse parameter mlpsa control order difference calculation control subtracted treatment. certain codings, defaul may end subtracting treatment control. plotting functions also updated reflect change. Changed minimum R requirement 3.0 since dependent packages require 3.0 (e.g. ggplot2). Updates compatibility ggplot 0.9. Fixed bug mlpsa.distribution.plot, extension plot.mlpsa function, fail treatment/control columns named TRUE/FALSE. Added plot.strata parameter loess.plot optionally draw vertical lines indicating strata.

title: multilevelPSA 1.1
text: Updated pisa demo use full PISA dataset using pisa package available http://github.com/jbryer/pisa. Added pisa.countries data frame. Can now pass parameters geom_smooth stat_smooth loess.plot. Fixed CITATION file include text version.

title: multilevelPSA 1.0
text: CRAN release: 2013-02-13 Initial version multilevelPSA package release February 13, 2013. Project hosted Github. information http://jbryer.github.com/multilevelPSA.
